entry.title: My Beginner guide to NGINX

entry.content:
One important knowledge a web developer must have is the ability to be able to manage their program from the server. The best known and widely used server is the localhost which hosts the programmers web application during the construction phase. For today most of this tasks have been taken over by third party solutions like AWS and Azure from Amazon and Microsoft respectively. With this blog I am going to try to install Nginx and host a simple static website with it from my own machine. 

Installation in Fedora

The operating system that I am going to use is Fedora Linux. This is my daily driver. The Nginx package is present in the dnf package manager. Run the following in the terminal.

sudo dnf install nginx

To be able to start and enable run the following commands. The enable commands allows the user not to start the instance of Nginx when they reboot the system.

# start
sudo systemctl start nginx

# enable
sudo systemctl enable nginx

# to stop
sudo systemctl stop nginx

# restart
sudo systemctl restart nginx

Nginx by default is usually on port 80. Open the browser and type on the header http://127.0.0.1:80. The following page will be displayed

For me the preferred port for Nginx is port 90. This is as there is Apache already installed in my system and in order to avoid conflicts. 

Adding the Static File

In order to do this, we are going to alter the Nginx configuration file. This is located in the /etc/nginx folder in Fedora. Navigate to this folder and open the nginx.conf file using your preferred text editor. For me its Neovim. Be sure to have super user rights. Add the following configurations to that file.

http {
    include mime.types; # this will prevent the css errors of text/plain
    server {
        listen 80; # the port to listen to. 
        location / {
            root /usr/share/nginx/html; # the folder containing the static pages to use
         }
    }
}

events {
}

We are going to add a HTML file with the following code. This will replace the index.html file in the /usr/share/nginx/html folder. 

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Welcome to Nginx</title>
     <link rel="stylesheet" href="./style.css"/>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Hello World, this is nginx</h1>
  </body>
</html>

Lets add CSS code that beautifies the above by giving the background a yellow background in a style.css file in the same folder.

body {
   background: yellow;
}

entry.title: Introduction to Bash Script
entry.summary: One of the first thing one learns when they start using a Linux OS distribution, they learn how to use the terminal. The terminal is available in different  operating systems. In Linux, the default is bash(Bourne Again Shell), in Mac OS it is zsh and…
entry.content:
One of the first thing one learns when they start using a Linux OS distribution, they learn how to use the terminal. The terminal is available in different  operating systems. In Linux, the default is bash(Bourne Again Shell), in Mac OS it is zsh and in Windows OS it is the Powershell. In Linux, the terminal is one of the most important things to learn. Some of the commands in the shell include:

  • cat - for displaying contents in a file
  • ls - for listing contents in directory
  • sudo - allows the user access root privileges
  • touch - creates a new file
  • cd - changes the directory
  • find - search for an item in a directory

In order to automate some commands bash allows users to create bash files. In this blog we are going to focus in bash files. 

In order to start we create a bash file with the extension .sh. Using sudo command we are going to make the file executable by running the following command on the terminal. Replace the script-file.sh with your own file name. 

sudo chmod +x script-file.sh

When running the above file you do the following 

./script-file.sh

In the following we are going to focus on displaying the results, variables and functions. 

Displaying results

The command used here is echo. Examples include: 

echo "Hello world";

Variables

The following way is how you initialise variables and do some simple arithmetic with them: 

# declaring and assigning a variable
phrase="I love bash scripting"
echo $phrase

Bash is not designed to do arithmetic. In order to perform such you add the expr function before the equation. 

# declaring, assigning integer variables and doing some math
x=1
y=2
z=`expr $x + $y`
echo "$x + $y = $z"

Comparisons

We will begin by string comparisons 

x="hello"
y="hello"

if [ $x=$y ]
then
    echo "x and y match"
elif [ $x!=$y ]
then 
    echo "x and y dont match"
fi

Now integer comparisons 

x=1
y=2

if [ $x -eq $y ] #equality
then 
    echo "they are both equal"
elif [ $x -gt $y ] # for greater than; use -lt for less than
then
    echo "$x is greater than $y"    
else
    echo "$x is less than $y"
fi

Functions

They can be made the following way 

# creating the function
hello(){
    echo "hello World"
}

# calling the function
hello

Function with parameters 

# creating the function
helloName(){
    echo "Hello $1"
}

name="John Doe"

helloName $name

entry.title: How to add Tailwind CSS to a vite project
entry.summary: Tailwind CSS is a CSS framework that utilizes classes with CSS code that only represent a singular CSS style rule.  The main advantage of it is that it allows a higher degree of freedom to the programmer. This is as compared to some frameworks like bootstrap…
entry.content:
Tailwind CSS is a CSS framework that utilizes classes with CSS code that only represent a singular CSS style rule. 

The main advantage of it is that it allows a higher degree of freedom to the programmer. This is as compared to some frameworks like bootstrap that offer generic code for each element. The main drawback of Tailwind is the use of many classes to achieve a single style that could be achieved by a dedicated CSS rule. This results in large code that feel too big to debug. This results to HTML code that looks like the following 

<!doctype html>
<html>
    <head>
        <meta charset="UTF-8">  
        <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">  
        <link href="/src/styles.css" rel="stylesheet">
    </head>
    <body>  
        <h1 class="text-3xl font-bold underline">    
            Hello world!  
        </h1>
    </body>
</html>

How to start

The following installation will be applicable with any framework installed using vite js. This include frameworks like Laravel, SvelteKit, React, Router, Nuxt and SolidJS. 

1. Install tailwind css in the folder containing the project 

npm install tailwindcss @tailwindcss/vite

2. Configure the vite plugin by altering the vite.config.js by adding the following 

import tailwindcss from '@tailwindcss/vite'
export default defineConfig({
    plugins: [tailwindcss()],
})

The following is how it will look like in react project 

import { defineConfig } from 'vite'
import tailwindcss from '@tailwindcss/vite'
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react'


export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [
        react(), 
        tailwindcss(),
      ],
})

3. Add the following on top of the css file 

@import "tailwindcss";

4. Start using in your project. An example in a react project 

<div>
    <h2 className="text-xl font-semibold text-gray-800 mb-4">
        Dashboard
    </h2>
</div>

entry.title: My love of Fedora Linux
entry.summary: The linux operating system is one of the most complicated operating system in terms of the number of distributions(distros) it has. This is as opposed to some of great competitors, Microsoft and Apple which have only Windows and Mac os respectively. For any one trying…
entry.content:
The linux operating system is one of the most complicated operating system in terms of the number of distributions(distros) it has. This is as opposed to some of great competitors, Microsoft and Apple which have only Windows and Mac os respectively. For any one trying linux for the first time, it is usually hard when it comes to choosing the first one. For me it was Ubuntu. But I have evolved after doing some soul searching while distro hopping.

Fedora Linux is one of the many distros that are associated with the linux operating system. It is associated with the Red Hat family distro. This are distros that use the dnf package manager and are based on the popular Red Hat enterprise Linux that is popular with the organizations. Fedora linux follows a release schedule where each version is released twice a year. As of writing it is Fedora 42. 

It is the distro that I currently use so I am familiar with it. 

Why I like fedora

Honestly speaking Fedora Linux was not my first choice when I migrated from Windows. My first distro was Ubuntu. I had a time when I was distro hopping(term used by linux enthusiasts who are constantly installing and reinstalling different distros.) I am happy to say that I have used distros such as Ubuntu, Debian, Kali linux, Linux Mint, Pop Os, Manjaro Linux and Parrot OS.

The simplicity of installation as opposed to other Linux distros. Of all the linux distros I have ever installed, fedora was the simplest one to install. I got give it to the creators. The installer is user centered. The default installer is a GUI based. It provides only the required configurations needed. When there are errors, it makes it easier to for the user to install. While the calamares installer used by most distros makes it easier to install the respective distros, nothing comes to the easiness and fewer instructions used to install the other distros.

The package manager. The dnf package manager is perfectly robust containing many packages for the applications that can be installed. It also allows other package managers like snap and flatpak. This drastically increases the number of applications that can be installed. 

The terminal. In fedora, while I am not sure about other distros, but in fedora if any command typed on it and the corresponding application not installed but available it searches its if it is available. If available it gives you a the option to install it. 

The community. The distro has a large vibrant community on the internet. For most problems where I can't get the answer to I just have to open my browser and google. Most times somebody usually has encountered the issue and fixed it. 

The project team. Many distros have their release cycles. For Fedora its twice a year. For someone who once had a debian systems and is anxious, the fact that the next system upgrade is definite makes me look up for the next while taking advantage of the existing one. For debian which is currently at 12, it is actually makes me more anxious worrying when the next update will be. 

Why I don't like it

The politics. Linux communities have a lot politics when it comes to the different distros. This is especially so damaging when starting. The point of contention with people and the red hat based distros is the commercial company of Red Hat. One of the reasons why I did not want to install it in the first place was the death of CentOs. Such overtures makes one insecure that maybe one day it may be Fedora.

The windows based apps. For most people, growing up we grew up in the windows ecosystem. This one affects all the linux distros. Applications such as the popular Microsoft office and visual studio, most games and proprietary software based by the adobe company cannot be used in windows. This is negative as some of this applications offer superior features and tools better than any linux based alternative can be able to offer. While applications like steam are trying to bridge that gap, I would have wished if they offered a native application for such.

Conclusion

In conclusion, getting into the linux community was one of my greatest adventures in the tech world. It allowed to feel in command of what I was doing and to learn more about how systems work. Hopefully for me I got to use Fedora and hope to be using it for years to come to learn more about it.
